plants.name: Camellia japonica
plants.description: An evergreen shrub native to eastern and southern Asia, producing large, showy flowers that bloom in winter and early spring. The flowers range in color from white, pink, to deep red, often fragrant and valued in gardens for winter color.
plants.location: East Asia, cultivated globally in mild temperate climates
plants.funFact: Camellia japonica flowers influenced the naming of the tea plant Camellia sinensis, though they are different species.

plants.name: Hamamelis virginiana
plants.description: A deciduous shrub or small tree native to eastern North America, witch hazel is notable for its yellow, spidery flowers that appear in late fall to winter. It is used in traditional medicine and skin care products.
plants.funFact: Its winter flowers are pollinated by moths and flies, which are active in colder months when other flowers are scarce.

plants.name: Helleborus niger
plants.description: A perennial herbaceous plant native to mountainous regions of Europe. Famous for its white to pink flowers that bloom in winter, often near the Christmas season, bringing color to cold gardens.
plants.location: European Alps, cultivated widely in temperate gardens
plants.funFact: Despite its common name, Christmas Rose is not a true rose but belongs to the buttercup family.

plants.name: Leptospermum scoparium
plants.description: A shrub or small tree native to New Zealand and southeast Australia. Manuka blooms predominantly in summer, but in some mild microclimates flowering can begin as early as late winter or early spring, producing white to pink flowers.
plants.funFact: Manuka honey, made from its nectar, is prized for its medicinal antibacterial properties.
